blocks.content: Inert gases such as nitrogen dissolve into your body during a dive. This is the basis for decompression sickness risk and no-decompression limits.
Nitrox (enriched air) reduces the fraction of nitrogen in your breathing gas. Less nitrogen generally means reduced nitrogen uptake at a given depth and time.
Divers commonly use Nitrox to increase no-decompression time on repetitive dives, add conservatism, or reduce post-dive fatigue (subjective reports vary).
Nitrox does not make you immune to decompression sickness. It reduces nitrogen exposure but introduces oxygen exposure limits.
A common misconception is that Nitrox allows you to dive deeper. Oxygen limits usually reduce maximum depth compared to air.

blocks.title: Practical takeaways
items: Use Nitrox to manage nitrogen exposure, not to exceed training limits.
Always analyze the cylinder yourself and label it clearly before the dive.
Plan depth based on MOD, not on how you feel.

blocks.content: Dalton’s Law: the total pressure of a gas mixture equals the sum of the partial pressures of each gas in that mixture.
P_total = PP_O2 + PP_N2 + PP_He
Partial pressure for one gas equals its fraction multiplied by the total absolute pressure.
P_gas = F_gas × P_total
Important: Always use absolute pressure (ATA or bar), not cylinder gauge pressure.
In seawater (metric), absolute pressure ≈ (Depth in meters / 10) + 1.
Example at 30 meters (≈4 ATA absolute pressure in seawater):

blocks.title: EAN32 (32% O₂ / 68% N₂) at 30m
items: Notice reduced nitrogen compared to air

blocks.title: EAN36 (36% O₂ / 64% N₂) at 30m
items: ppO₂ now exceeds 1.4 ATA working limit

blocks.content: EAN36 at 30m produces a ppO₂ of 1.44 ATA. This exceeds a common working limit of 1.4 ATA and illustrates why MOD must always be respected.
During a dive, inert gases (primarily nitrogen, and sometimes helium) dissolve into tissues. Over time at a constant depth, tissues move toward saturation at that ambient pressure.
On ascent, ambient pressure decreases and tissues off-gas. Ascend and decompress according to your training and the plan.
This app reinforces gas concepts and MOD/EAD/END logic. It is not a decompression planner.

Narcosis is a reversible impairment that can occur at depth. Nitrogen is a primary contributor. Many technical diving models also treat oxygen as narcotic, while helium is considered minimally narcotic.
END (Equivalent Narcotic Depth) estimates narcotic effect relative to air at a shallower depth.
Individual susceptibility varies significantly. END is a planning tool, not a guarantee of performance.
Trimix blends may contain reduced oxygen fractions. If oxygen percentage is too low, the gas may not support consciousness at shallow depth or the surface.
Hypoxic Trimix (typically below 16% oxygen) is not breathable at the surface and requires appropriate travel gas and training.

categories.title: Oxygen Management
categories.description: ppO₂ limits, oxygen toxicity, and exposure concepts.

blocks.content: ppO₂ equals oxygen fraction multiplied by absolute pressure. As depth increases, ppO₂ increases.
ppO2 = FO2 × (Depth/10 + 1)
This formula assumes metric units in seawater (depth in meters).
A ppO₂ of 1.4 ATA is commonly used for working portions of dives to provide a safety margin. 1.6 ATA is typically reserved for decompression or short contingency exposure.
Example: EAN36 (36% O₂) with a working limit of 1.4 ATA.
Diving EAN36 to 30 meters would exceed a 1.4 ATA working limit and increase risk of central nervous system (CNS) oxygen toxicity.
Always follow your agency standards and training when selecting oxygen limits.
CNS oxygen toxicity is associated with elevated ppO₂. Symptoms can appear suddenly and require immediate action according to training.
CNS oxygen toxicity risk increases with higher ppO₂ and longer exposure. It can occur without warning and may result in convulsions underwater.

blocks.caption: VENTID is a common mnemonic used for symptom awareness.

blocks.content: A convulsion underwater can lead to loss of regulator and drowning. This is why working limits are conservative.
If you suspect CNS symptoms, follow your training and team procedures. Avoid treating mnemonics as diagnostic tools.
Pulmonary oxygen toxicity relates to longer exposures to elevated oxygen partial pressures. It is commonly managed through dose models (e.g., OTUs/CNS%).
Pulmonary oxygen toxicity develops from prolonged exposure to moderately elevated oxygen partial pressures. It affects the lungs rather than the central nervous system.
Technical divers track cumulative exposure using OTUs (Oxygen Tolerance Units) or CNS% models during repetitive or decompression diving.
For most recreational Nitrox use, pulmonary toxicity is less limiting than CNS considerations, but it becomes more relevant in technical/decompression diving.
This app does not calculate OTUs/CNS%. Use appropriate planning tools for decompression diving.

categories.title: Planning Tools
categories.description: How MOD, EAD, and END relate to gas fractions.

blocks.content: MOD is the maximum depth at which a chosen ppO₂ limit is not exceeded for a given oxygen fraction.
This formula assumes metric units in seawater (result in meters).

blocks.title: Common usage
items: Pick ppO₂ (often 1.4 for working, 1.6 for contingency/deco)
Use the mix you will actually breathe at depth
Label the cylinder with mix and MOD after analysis

blocks.content: EAD estimates the depth at which air would produce the same nitrogen partial pressure as your Nitrox mix. It is commonly used to reference air-based tables.
EAD is a planning concept. Follow your agency’s method and tools for decompression planning.
A common modern approach treats both nitrogen and oxygen as narcotic, while helium is considered minimally narcotic.
Different communities and agencies may use different assumptions (e.g., oxygen narcotic or not). Use the approach taught in your training.
Dalton’s Triangle is a memory aid that helps you rearrange the relationship between partial pressure, fraction, and absolute pressure.

blocks.caption: Cover the unknown to derive the formula from the remaining two.

categories.title: Equipment & Procedures
categories.description: Practical steps for analysis, labeling, and oxygen compatibility.

blocks.title: Before the dive
items: Analyze the cylinder with a calibrated analyzer
Confirm the cylinder you analyzed is the one you will dive
If diving as a team, cross-check gas where appropriate

blocks.content: Procedures vary by shop, agency, and team. Follow local and training standards.
Labeling is a communication tool: it reduces errors and helps maintain consistency between analysis, planning, and execution.

blocks.title: What to write on a label

blocks.content: Higher oxygen fractions increase fire risk and require oxygen-compatible procedures and equipment. A common threshold discussed in training is above 40% oxygen.
Follow your agency and gas supplier guidance for oxygen cleaning and compatibility. Do not assume equipment is oxygen-clean without proper service.
Oxygen-rich environments require special consideration: compatible materials, clean systems, and correct handling reduce risk.
This topic is deeper than a short reference. Use recognized training and supplier standards for equipment in oxygen service.
